objects.name: txt_label
objects.string:
Hello and welcome to the SG Institute of Juice
Enjoy your time at the game feel test range.
V. 1.0
(LMouse): Fire
(RMouse): Move
Consult the event comments to learn more.

events.comment:
Hi There

This is a collection of small effects, tricks and general tips for making your game feel better. I'll also briefly touch on subjects like camera movement and sound design so you have a pretty broad tutorial example at hand.

Please note that this is an intermediate tutorial. It won't explain every single step to make these things, rather you are supposed to look at and coppy the events/objects and figure some stuff out yourself. You'll need some understanding of how GDev works in general and how variables and object variables work in particular. If you are new to GDevelop you should do other tutorials first.

Many of the systems here work with game states, so things like screenshake etc have 
a) events that can initialize them from anywhere in the game and 
b) events that govern their behavior once initialised.

Also I'd like to note that, while I uses these technique in and action game context, they are applicable to nearly any type of games. If you look at recent entries for deck builders or strategy games you'll see at least some of the techniques used. And speaking of reference games: I tried to mention examples of games that use these techniques to good effect as often as possible. 

For further reference on why this stuff is important I recommend Jan Willem Nijmans video on the topic: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AJdEqssNZ-U

- Comments always refer to the event that comes bellow them.
- Comment colors indicate categories:
Yellow - General
Orange - VFX
Blue - SFX
Red - Camera
Just initialising the scene here, nothing to see, move along to the juicy bits ;)
Activate this to hide cam and direction helper.

---Camera Object and Player Tracking---

Let's start with some camera work. Here we use our players move state to change how the camera tracks the player.

Note that we work with a "cam_target" object that we later focus the camera on. Doing this instead of focusing directly on the player entity gives us more freedom for handling camera movement. For example you can now apply forces or movement tweens to your camera. You'll generally want to hide that cam_target, I just left it visible for demonstration sake.

If the player does not move then the cam_target slowly lerps to the player position. Using lerp in camera movement is almost always a good idea. Even if you want a super snappy camera you might still want to use a very faint lerp. Your own eyesight and focus is lerped too and a camera that targets the player rigidly and perfectly will usually feel artificial and off.

The second event works pretty much the same, but uses a point on another helper object that tracks the players movement direction. This way we can have the camera trail ahead while the player moves. Look at the ui_move_direction animation for reference. You can get a lot of different results using helper objects, points and different lerps, going way beyond a camera that just tracks the player.

Reference: Luftrausers, SYNTHETIK

---Angle Snapping on Rotating Pixelart---

Note that we decrease the rotation of the weapon by a factor, then round it and multiply it up again with the same factor. This has it "snap" to fixed angle intervals. In some circumstances this can make your art look better since the object does not constantly rotate even on the slightest movement. Especially advisable for when you rotate pixel art. You can use smaller round intervals to make the effect less noticeable.

Reference: Enter the Gungen, Nuclear Throne

---Slight General Randomization---

Also note that we apply a lot of small randomizations in many places (shots aren't perfectly accurate, have slight speed variations, trail animations starts at random frames, casings eject on slightly random angles).  In a game, imperfection is perfection, because actual perfection drops the facade.  Generally the more regular and static your game behaves the more artificial it appears, so in most cases you want your game to have these slight inaccuracies everywhere.  Even the slightest randomization will still have this effect, even if you think it's not even notieceable.

---Cam Recoil---

Cam recoil can reinforce powerful movement and forces. You can use distance conditions on your cam_target to keep the effect in check. Both moving and limiting the camera this way isn't really possible without a cam_target object.

Reference: Nuclear Throne

---Small VFX---

Just adding small VFX to pretty much any action that occurs ingame can go a long way for making it more lively.

Mirror randomization can be an efficient way to give variance to your VFX. In this example we only have a single muzzle flash sprite but since it is asymmetrical and only shows for a few frame we can have it appear more varied by just mirroring it randomly.

---Shot Trail---

This creates an animated shot trail that follows your shot to the target. We'll see how it is handled further down.

Reference: Enter the Gungeon

---Random Falling Objects, Permanence and Mass Object Fade Out---

Here we create casing from our weapon that fall to the ground and remain in the level.
But first we do a opacity reduction to slowly fade out any casings that where previously spawned. You can adjust this to your liking and make more complex despawn behaviors with object variables.

These casings are just one example of how your action can permanently affect your environment. Overall this makes the game world more tangible. Just make sure you keep it efficient and manage your objects. The actual casing removal happens further down.

Reference: Hotline Miami
Enable this to trigger screenshake on firing.

--Dynamic Ambient Mix--

Here we explore a couple very basic sound design tweaks. First note that we change the ambiance volume (applied elsewhere to the levels ambient noise) to give more room to your weapon sound. Generally you want to mix down less important things to draw more attention to relevant actions, player and enemy sound in particular. The ambiance fades in quickly after each shot.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--SFX Variances---

We also randomize the weapon sound on each shot. This is another case where slight variants make things more tangible and feel more real, regardless if this is actually realistic. Most of all this prevents sounds from tiring out your ears.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--Dynamic SFX Vol---

Dynamic volume reduction on repetitive sound is another way to prevent sounds from getting obtrusive. On weapons that can also help emphasizing the first shot/opening attack. 

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--Dynamic SFX Pitch---

Here we increase a pitch variable each time a fire sound is played. This way we give feedback on longer attack actions and overall make the action feel less samy again.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--Sound Layering---

Here we fade in another sound that combines with our main gun sound after the max pitch is reached. You can use this kind of layering to all kinds of ends (for when players run out of ammo for example, or to layer in echo in open spaces etc). 

The clang sound also uses a different kind of variance where it randomizes its pitch each time it is played. This way you can get more mileage out of sounds even if you only have a single variant of it on file.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

---Dynamic Sound Reset---

In this example we reset everything with the same event, but you might want to differentiate this more once you do a lot of sound handling.

--Ambiance Vol Reset---

This brings back your ambiance after it has been ducked.

---Shot Trail Scaling---

Here we handle our shot trail. Note that the factor we divide the trail by is shorter than the actual sprite. The trail has a lot of glow but the actual trail is only 96px long. Also look at the vfx_shot_trail animation and note that the origin/center is at the point where the trail physically starts, since that is the position we want it to extend from.

Using the linked object conditions comes with the advantage that the trail will stop growing as soon as the shot is removed, but you might want to adjust that if you need different behaviors.

With good sprites you can make this quite a nice effect, but there are limits due to the fact that this uses stretching in order to scale the trail. There might be a better method to do this in future version of GDevelop.

---Casing Handling---

This makes casings hit the ground and stop moving. The random angle further adds to the effect and since it only does a position check you can do it on a lot of objects before it becomes taxing.

---Cam Shake Initialization---

Here we initiate our camera shake. Actual shake execution is handled further down. shake_magnitude affects how far the camera can move from your target on each shake, shake_count governs how many shakes are executed. Shake_growth changes shake magnitude after each shake, negative values make your shake decline as it goes on, with positive values you can create growing shake.

Note that his shake call uses = and will therefore overwrite any existing shake. You can make additive shake with using + on count and growth, but you also might want to use conditions for those values or your shake might get out if hand if it gets triggered too often in a short time.

Reference: Everything from Vlambeer.

---Screenshake Handling---

Now lets finally do some screenshake! First note that we only focus the camera directly on our cam_target while screenshake is not executing.

Reference: every  Vlambeer game

While in the shake state we randomize these variables on each shake, with the shake target positions still being based on our cam_target. Then we focus the camera on our shake position. Note that this does not happen while we also execute hitlag, since shake frequency would be affected by hitlag slowdown and would result in very slow shake.
The fact that we do the shake based on variables instead of directly applying it to the camera allows to do it to any cameras you might have in the scene, shaking each in the same way.

You can also incorporate randomized camera angles into your shake (activate this event to see the effect ingame). This makes the shake more chaotic, decide yourself if you want that. Tweak the numers to make the effect more ore less pronounced.
Here we change our shake on each execution, depending on the _growth variable.

This has us exit the shake state whenever we run out of _count or _magnitude. We also reset the shake variables to make sure we completely exit the shake state. Resetting _growth has the benefit that you don't need to set it on each common shake.

---Triggering Hitlag---

This initializes hitlag. 0.03 effectively means 0.3 seconds of slowdown, since the hitlag duration is itself affected by the slowdown. 0.3 is very heavy hitlag, you'll want to tune this to your preference and like many things here, you'll probably want to enable the player to change the effects in your game's options.

Like screenshake, hitlag can be made to overwrite existing hitlag with = and can be made to add to existing lag with +. You might again need limiters as conditions or your additive hitlag might turn into full on slowmo if triggered rapidly.

Reference: Early arcade fighting games, Dead Cells

---Handling Hitlag---

If your game uses variable times scale you need to make sure that the hitlag resets you scale to a variable instead. Here we always reset the time scale to 1 after the effect wears off.

I prefer a 90% slowdown to total hit stop, but your mileage may vary. Using slowdown has the added benefit that you can use the hitlag system to trigger general slow motion effects too.

Reference: SUPER HOT

---Triggering Hitflash---

This changes an objects color on hit and the variable affects how long it will "flash" in that color. Classic hitflashing would make the object turn white, you can achieve this using the blink extension.

Reference: Hollow Knight

---Hitflash Reseting---

This causes objects to reset to their normal color once they run out of hitflash time. If you regularly recolor your objects with events ingame you'll need to give them a color variable to reset to, otherwise the hitlag reset will overwrite the color you gave them via other events.

---Triggering Jelly Wobble---

This whole effect can probably also achieved using the tween behavior on objects. In a way the following showcases what tweens actually do behind the scenes. Making these behaviors yourself might give you more gradual control in some areas.

This makes objects wobble as if made of jelly. We handle that in detail further down. Note that we also change the object scale here to properly initialize the jelly wobbling.

---Jelly Wobble Handling---

I don't fully understand how this works (saw this in another non-GDev tutorial once) but essentially we have a variable that oscillates (?) due to the lerp (?!?) and that is applied to x-scale directly and y-scale invertedly (?!?!?). Anyway, it just works, so copy that code and tinker till the result fits. :D 

Objects that are jelly scaled need to have their own obj_scale_lerp variable between 1 and >0. This affects how rigidly the object wobbles, higher values make it wobble less and faster basically.

Note that we did a + to the width here, so how you change the object scale when initializing the wobbling also affects how it subsequently executes. I generally go with something like 1.5 for x and 0.5 for y. You don't want to go too low on your y or too high on your x or the wobbly will execute with a lot of 0 scaling.
The is_squishy variable affects how long the object is considered for wobbling independent from whether the effect is still discernible.

---Small VFX---

Just adding small animated VFX to pretty much any action that occurs ingame can go a long way for making it more lively. Make some of these effects permanent or long lasting further adds to the "realness" of your world. Here we use seperate evenst to do three things:

1. We spawn a small impact where the shot hit.
2. We spawn a floor effect that remains in the scene and uses the same "fade out exisiting objects" as our casing system.
3. We also re-use our casing system to spawn some particles that fly off the target, because we are lazy and lazy is efficient.

These are just a few examples of what you can do. Generally the more individually differentiated VFX you add to a thing the more interesting but also pronounced it becomes. Further note that some of these VFX are affected by our attack angle. VFX reacting to their source this way will add to their plausibility.

---Spawning Float Text---

here we spawn imaginary damage numbers to give more feedback on attacks. We use a lot of forces here to make the text move with the attack, away from the target and also continuously downwards as if affected by gravity.

Reference: Pretty much every JRPG

---Spawning Float Text---

The is_new variable triggers some general text handling but you might want to handle this difference. Chances are that if your game uses float text, it'll use it a lot and everywhere, so you might want to streamline the actions that'll affect every float text.

Reference: Pretty much every JRPG

---Spawning Float Text---

Here we dynamically change our float text to a custom behavior if our attacks crit. Note the movement change and is_new switch off, making the text rise up instead of being affected by the usual downwards text gravity.

Reference: Pretty much every JRPG

--Float Text Handling---

We use a oppacity variable to both have the text fade out and be removed once it reaches zero, but you can handle this as you see fit.
Here we fiddle with our texts size to position it centered correctly at the point we spawned it and give it some downward gravity too.
Whether you want to do this scale down also depends on your preference. Since GDev text uses top left as origin the scaling wont work so nicely on larger text.

---Objects/Text Flashing Through Multiple Colors--

And lastly we have an event that makes a text go through a set of colors. You can adjust variables and colors to change frequency and the like. Introduce a flash_count variable and you can have it stop flashing after a set number of executions. You can also use less and more colors by changing the point at which it resets _progress to 0. Additional is_flashy_x states in objects can trigger flashes of different if you define them. They can use the same flash_timer/flash/progress.

This effect can easily be applied to sprites too, but note that text color and sprite color are changed with different actions.
You'd use the below events if you want to add additional colors to the flashing. Moving the _flash_progress = 0 to the end is also required to make this work.

I hope these examples where usefull. Feel free to experiment with the events and copy anything you want to use.

If you want to see these techniques in actions you can check out my free games on 
itch.io https://sleeper-games.itch.io/ 
or my comercial stuff on Steam 
https://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Sleeper%20Games

You can also find me on Twitter:
https://twitter.com/Sleeper_Games

Cheers!
Stefan - Sleeper Games
